title: Refactor wiki model specs to avoid using instance variables
description:
## Summary

<!--
Please briefly describe what part of the code base needs to be refactored.
-->

The following discussion from !27428 should be addressed:

- [ ] @.luke started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/27428#note_320730016):  (+1 comment)

    > :thinking: The `#delete_page` and `#update_page` specs are ported from older specs. Is it worth creating a follow-up issue to look at whether we can avoid instance variables in these tests? I think I would prefer that not to happen in this MR, as being able to see the clean porting of the code gives a reviewer confidence that what once worked will still work again.

## Improvements

<!--
Explain the benefits of refactoring this code.
See also https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/values/index.html#say-why-not-just-what
-->

Replace instance variables with `let` bindings.

We did a similar refactor for the `WikiPage` specs in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/24364.

## Involved components

<!--
List files or directories that will be changed by the refactoring.
-->

- `spec/support/shared_examples/models/wiki_shared_examples.rb`

description: Replace the filtered search bar with the gitlab-ui component. This will allow us to use patterns that we use elsewhere and should allow for easier extensibility.

title: Consolidate CI minutes logic under `Ci::Minutes` namespace
description:
## Problem

The current state of the code has several problems:

1. Currently this logic is spread across methods in `Namespace`, `NamespaceStatistics` and `NamespacesHelper` classes.
1. These with methods cross reference each other in a way that is hard to understand the logic.
1. All methods are public, so they are all potentially being used in the view, making refactoring difficult.
1. Test coverage for some of these methods is low given the criticality around purchased CI minutes.

## Solution

We have started a series of refactorings to bring all this logic under a new `Ci::Minutes` namespace where it will be centralized under specific domain responsibility.

title: Run `*-as-if-foss` jobs on master only
description:
## Opportunity

`rspec * as-if-foss` jobs cost `$15,139.61` for [March 2020](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/590833/WIP:-Kyle-Wiebers-Scratchpad?widget=8344131&udv=0) (`2211.11+1373.70+6052.90+5501.90`). 

### Detailed Analysis

`*-as-if-foss` jobs are expensive and may have a situation where adding the jobs manually may be more cost effective. Based on my initial analysis it looks like [the costs of the `rspec as-if-foss` jobs](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/590833/WIP:-Kyle-Wiebers-Scratchpad?widget=8344131&udv=0) for March were $18,525.30. Over the last 30 days there have been 1,638 of 674,062 builds (0.24%) where the associated [`*-as-if-foss` job failed and the non foss job succeeded](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/590833/WIP:-Kyle-Wiebers-Scratchpad?widget=8343893&udv=0).

I know the `*-as-if-foss` jobs safeguard against foss failures but perhaps there's a solution we can consider to reduce the frequency of these jobs. 

- Could these be manual for merge requests?
  - Could there be a job in the `test` stage which "plays" a subset of the foss jobs depending on which files are changed? 
- Is there some configuration of `changes:` that can be used to reduce the frequency of `always` jobs for foss? 

## Proposal

- [ ] Run `rspec *-as-if-foss` jobs for `gitlab-org/gitlab` master and `gitlab-org/security/gitlab` MRs.`rspec * -as-if-foss` jobs should be manual in `gitlab-org/gitlab` MRs

### Expected outcomes

- Reduce [cost per pipeline KPI](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/performance-indicators/#average-cost-per-merge-request-pipeline-for-gitlab) to $1.90
- Decrease `gitlab-org/gitlab` pipeline costs by $10,000 per month
- Decrease in the [master pipeline success rate](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/performance-indicators/#scheduled-pipeline-success-rate-for-master-branch-in-gitlab-project) due to foss errors being acceptable master failures

### Future iteration

- If foss error rate is high further experiment with using `changes` or a component to selectively execute some `-as-if-foss` jobs based on the files that are changed.

title: [Design Management] Improve design management image loads by frontend avoiding refetching image urls for designs if it already has them
description:
Looking at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/207351/designs we see a loading spinner every time we click on a design to enlarge it, even after closing the modal and clicking again to enlarge the same image.

After https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/202530 the backend now instructs the browser to refer to its cache rather than to re-query the design. 

The loading spinning time is due to the frontend first querying for the design's `image` property (the URL to the design, and not the design file itself). The frontend performs this query repeatedly whenever the design is enlarged. Because the `image` property will never change, it's safe to refer to a previously cached value instead of re-querying. If we did that, the large design would appear instantly on successive views of the enlarged design.

title: Add authentication config information to usage ping
description:
## Problem

Currently, we only track LDAP in the self-managed feedback we receive back in [usage ping](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/lib/ee/gitlab/usage_data.rb). For us to be able to better understand which authentication strategies we should invest in, we should get some basic information on what instances tend to use.

## Proposal

Please add the following to usage ping under the `usage_activity_by_stage_manage` method. Please indicate in usage ping whether an instance is using:
* [LDAP](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/auth/ldap.html)
* [OmniAuth](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/integration/omniauth.html), and which provider
* [SAML SSO for Groups](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/saml_sso/)
* Open registration (username/password registration)

Returning the number of users can be left out of this iteration. If an instance has the method configured, return true. If not, return false.

Note that each method should be tracked separately (e.g. `using_ldap`, `using_omniauth`, `using_saml_sso`) so we're aware when an instance is using multiple authentication methods. 

Edit: I'm adding open registration as something to track, as well.

## Issue readiness

* [x]  Product: issue description is accurate with an acceptable proposal for an MVC
* [x]  Engineering: issue is implementable with few remaining questions, is sufficiently broken down, and is able to be estimated

title: Investigate moving the Package Registry from EE to Core
description:
~"backend-weight::2" 

### Topic to Evaluate
[GitLab recently announced 18 features are moving to open source](https://about.gitlab.com/blog/2020/03/30/new-features-to-core/). This includes support for a set of [package managers](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/) so all your packages can stay in one place. 

Prior to making those features available to the community for free, we need to better the implications of making this change and come up with a plan to do it. The outcome of the investigation will be a set of weighted and scheduled issues in the epic https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2867.

### Tasks to  Evaluate

- [ ] Determine feasibility of moving the Package Registry from ~"GitLab Premium" to ~"GitLab Core" 
- [ ] Create issue(s) for implementation and add them to the epic https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2867
- [ ] Set weight on implementation issue(s)
- [ ] If weight is greater than 5, break issue into smaller issues

### Risks and Implementation Considerations 


## Breakdown of the files to be moved

**Note** This list does not include the spec files. For each file listed here, there is likely a matching spec file that will also need to be moved.

This list is not yet complete and is still in progress.

The package stage consists of three main components: The APIs that package manager clients interact with to push/pull and work with packages, the GitLab frontend views that display package information, the GitLab backend that supports those frontend views.

This migration will involve moving all of those components and their associated tests from `ee` locations to non-ee locations in addition to removing the [license restriction](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e431ed9d64ef1111712f0770916dc3f0f9cccffc/ee/app/models/license.rb#L91) and related code.

To begin, I believe we should move the front end code and all of it's supporting backend code first. This will allow packages to display on the front end for core, and as we move each package manager, we shouldn't need to further change the front end

These MRs will all be very large, but as long as they are limited to only file movement, the reviews should be straightforward and move quickly.

One of the biggest challenges will be dealing with the shared backend code.

### Client API

title: Insights / report page embeddable in the GitLab Handbook
description: ### Context The Development and Quality groups use Sisense charts embedded in Handbook pages ([example](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/performance-indicators/)) to monitor department performance indicators. Both groups have expressed willingness to dogfood Analytics for specific KPIs if we can produce appropriate computations. ### Problem to Solve This issue extends [Report Pages](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3214) by allowing a user to embedded a chart. A user with appropriate permissions can choose to make a specific chart publicly viewable and obtain a link or other instructions for embedding into a handbook page much as Sisense does. ### Proposal 1. A button with pop-up copies iframe code to the clipboard which can be pasted into an html page. See this design note. 1. This MVC works only for public projects. A follow-on issue will address on granting permissions to private projects. 1. This embedded chart is not a snapshot of the data, but a live run of the repot. 1. A separate page will render a layout specifically for embeds but no changes to REST API are expected. 1. Hide the feature behind a feature flag. Use gitlab-org group for beta test. 1. Consider future adaptation of this feature for Generic Reports Page while developing. ### Visual See this design note. ### Examples from our Handbook Some example pages are [Engineering KPI Handbook Page](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/performance-indicators) or [Quality KPI Handbook Page](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/performance-indicators/). See the [erb template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/blob/master/source/includes/_performance_indicator.erb#L27) that renders these charts in the handbook. The erb file is consuming this [data file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/blob/master/data/performance_indicators.yml). See also more details about [how the page works](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/performance-indicators/#how-to-work-with-pages-like-this). It appears to be doing something like: ``` ``` Sisense [documentation](https://dtdocs.sisense.com/article/chart-options#ShareLink). ### Reference This story is a child of &3049.

Modify https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/updating_the_geo_nodes.html:

* [ ] Describe and link to https://docs.gitlab.com/omnibus/settings/database.html#upgrading-a-geo-instance to prevent customers from unexpectedly upgrading PG and adding a lot of downtime

title: Document Elasticsearch re-indexing using an alias
description: As we have recently made changes to reduce Elasticsearch cluster disk space, our self-managed customers may need to reindex their Elasticsearch cluster to take advantage of these improvements. To help them minimize the downtime caused by the re-indexing, we may want to document some of the best practice we have found and share it with our customers.

title: License Compliance - sort detected in project licenses by classification: denied
description:
As a follow up issue to [Match displayed policies](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28862)
we want to improve the UX experience by sorting by classification 'denied' first.

<details><summary>View UI</summary>
![uxready](/uploads/252fb58c88b33560fb108cbacc1e20b0/uxready.png)
</details>

## What this issue covers

### Implement

Make use of the **:sort_by** and **:sort_direction** params made available by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213592. This issue is just the ~frontend portion.

### Approach

Should be a easy win. All we need to do is ee/app/assets/javascripts/license_compliance/store/modules/list/actions.js

From:
```
      params: {
        per_page: 10,
        page: state.pageInfo.page || 1,
        ...params,
      },
```


To:

```
      params: {
        per_page: 10,
        page: state.pageInfo.page || 1,
        sort_by: 'denied'
        ...params,
      },
```

** We should create a constant for 'denied' to live in ee/app/assets/javascripts/license_compliance/store/modules/list/constants.js

It would be a bit odd of a pattern for this vuex module to reference a constant outside of it's module.

We already have ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/license_compliance/constants.js

```
export const LICENSE_APPROVAL_CLASSIFICATION = {
  ALLOWED: 'allowed',
  DENIED: 'denied',
};
```

Not sure of the correct pattern here. Maybe abstract the mutual constant into another constant file? 

## Clarification on why we need sort

We paginate the license results. 10 results per page.

Sorting by classification `denied` first (`policy violation: denied` label) first is needed because if a license with a policy violation happens to be on a page > 1, then it will be confusing for the use to see the "policy violation" alert banner, but no policy violations visible on the first page of results (this is the default set of data that is loaded).

title: [FE] Visually depict Value Stream Analytics stages as a flow
description:
### Description

> As we start to realign value stream analytics as a flow, we should arrange our stages to visually depict a value chain. Our current approach reads top-to-bottom, which doesn't really depict a linear flow.

### Solution

Implement the component from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-design/-/issues/1080 and integrate it into VSA.

### Additional information

The stages being represented will match the order of the original (vertical) feature and custom stages will be excluded. 

**Note:** The current feature's `total` value is returned from the backend as `production` and will need to be relabelled to `overview` for this feature.

### Checklist
- [x] Implement `gitlab-ui` component
- [x] Integrate `path` component into VSA

title: Exclude bot users from `User#gitlab_employee?` method
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

`User#gitlab_employee?` is used to display a "GitLab Team Member" badge on the frontend (see #212259) but if a bot user has an `@gitlab.com` email address then it will get the "GitLab Team Member" badge. 

These are bots I could find (with an exception of a few actual users): https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/project_members?utf8=%E2%9C%93&search=bot


### Steps to reproduce

https://staging.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/3682


### What is the current *bug* behavior?

`User#gitlab_employee?` returns `true` for a bot that has a `@gitlab.com` email

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

`User#gitlab_employee?` should return `false` for a bot that has a `@gitlab.com` email

### Possible fixes

Possibly add a regex check to exclude users that have a username that starts with `gitlab` and ends with `bot`.

title: Geo: Package file replication should adhere to selective sync settings
description:
If a data type is nested beneath a project or namespace, then it should observe selective sync rules.

At the moment, Package Files will be synced on creation via events, regardless of selective sync.

We missed this because we haven't had to deal with it for Uploads/Artifacts/LFS Objects yet since those don't have events.

Backfill will already observe selective sync because it will leverage RegistryConsistencyWorker.

## Proposal 1

There are many layers we could check selective sync in, but I'm thinking we could do something like this in `BlobReplicatorStrategy`:

```ruby
def download
  return if excluded_by_selective_sync?
  
  ::Geo::BlobDownloadService.new(replicator: self).execute
end
```

And in the base class `Replicator`:

```ruby
def excluded_by_selective_sync?
  return false unless selective_sync_enabled?

  if selective_sync_by_namespaces?
    selective_sync_by_namespaces_excludes?(parent_namespace_id)
  elsif selective_sync_by_shards?
    selective_sync_by_projects_excludes?(parent_project_id)
  else
    false
  end
end

def selective_sync_by_namespaces_excludes?(namespace_id)
  return false unless namespace_id

  !selected_namespaces_and_descendants.where(id: namespace_id).any?
end

def selective_sync_by_projects_excludes?(project_id)
  return false unless project_id

  !selected_projects.where(id: project_id).any?
end

def selective_sync_not_implemented_error(method_name)
  raise NotImplementedError,
      "#{self.class} does not implement #{method_name}. If selective sync is not application, just return nil."
end

def parent_namespace_id
  namespace_id = parent_project&.namespace_id
  # We should never see this at runtime-- we must have appropriate tests that check/trigger this for any Blob
  selective_sync_not_implemented_error(__method__) unless namespace_id

  namespace_id
end

def parent_project_id
  # We should never see this at runtime-- we must have appropriate tests that check/trigger this for any Blob
  selective_sync_not_implemented_error(__method__) unless model_record.respond_to?(:project_id)

  model_record.project_id
end

```

I didn't define all methods, but the idea is that all blobs that respond to `#project_id` "just work". The assumption is that `#project_id`, if available, will always mean the parent project.

All blobs that don't respond to `#project_id` will fail specs with readable errors unless `#parent_project_id` and `#parent_namespace_id` are defined on their specific Replicator class.

description:

## What

Default the `:geo_self_service_framework_replication` feature flag to enabled.

## Owners

- Team: @geo-team 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_geo`
- Best individual to reach out to: @mkozono

## Expectations

###Â What are we expecting to happen?

~~On staging.gitlab.com, Package Files of Projects selected for sync should be replicated to the secondary.~~

Worst case is probably errors during creation of package files. Next might be errors in Geo-related jobs.

Prod:

## Beta groups/projects

N/A

## Roll Out Steps

- [-] Enable on staging

title: Document Group Export/Import UI functionality
description:
### Problem to solve

Document the new ability to use GitLab UI to initiate Export and Import of Groups. Until now, Group Export/Imports were only available through the [API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/group_import_export.html).

This ability already exists for [Projects](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/settings/import_export.html). Groups will follow the same pattern in the UI.

The new feature is described in this [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2888) and the issues attached to that epic. The best contacts in regard to the final details and screenshots are the engineers assigned to the issues.

title: Increase Requirement title character length to support longer entries
description:
### Summary
Currently, users are unable to create or edit requirements to be greater than 255 characters. This limit may not support some longer requirements users may want to create. This issue is to discuss different ways we can address this and what the implications would be, as well as what we believe to be a good limit for MVC.

@kushalpandya has implemented an error message while creating/editing requirements to inform users of this limitation, which is a great improvement in providing additional detail to users of this current limitation. This will still be useful as we discuss increasing this limit, as we will want to ensure requirements don't become too long (if we receive feedback after increasing the limit that this needs to be greater, that would suggest a detail page with a longer description field is needed). 


/cc @kushalpandya @jprovaznik @mjwood

title: Geo: Implement backfill of PackageFiles/Blobs
description:
This should require very little PackageFile-specific code, since replication of new PackageFiles with events should already be implemented.

The true goal is implementation of Self-Service Framework and its documentation.

## Proposal

- [ ] ~~`RegistryConsistencyWorker` creates missing `PackageFileRegistry` records (this worker already exists, just add `PackageFileRegistry` to its list, for now)~~ => https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217863
- [x] Another worker (e.g. `RegistrySyncWorker`, I can't think of a reason why it would be Blob-specific) enqueues sync jobs for registries needing sync
  - This is currently handled by e.g. `FileDownloadDispatchWorker`, and we should copy as much as we need, but I strongly recommend not reusing it as-is.
  - This is our best opportunity to change that logic without risk.
    - Use a worker that doesn't run long, e.g. `Reenqueuer`
    - We now have a Replicator "interface".
    - Sync concurrency settings should apply across event-triggered syncs as well, not just backfill ones, so it should not be managed solely within this worker. Instead, concurrency limits should be handled further down, in the worker doing syncing. So, for this issue we can ignore concurrency limits. Later, we can stop enqueuing jobs from this worker if we are already at the concurrency limit.
  - Optionally, make it sync only "unsynced" in 1 MR, then also "failed" and "missing on primary" in another MR.
- [x] We can reuse `Geo::EventWorker` as sync jobs, see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v12.9.2-ee/ee/lib/gitlab/geo/log_cursor/events/event.rb#L11: `::Geo::EventWorker.perform_async(event.replicable_name, event.event_name, event.payload)`. E.g. `::Geo::EventWorker.perform_async("package_file", "created", { "model_record_id" => 4 })`
- [ ] Anything that needs to be done in order to add a new blob must be added to https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/geo/framework.html#blob-replicator-strategy. After following the doc, there should be sufficient specs in place that guarantee Geo support of the new blob.

title: Delete Releases in UI of "Edit Release" page
description:
### Problem to solve

Today, users are able to delete a release via the [Release API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/releases/index.html#delete-a-release). In order to support all the capabilities in the UI, we need to enable users to delete the Release.

#### User story

As a user, I want to be able to delete a release using the UI, so that I can easily manage my release entries without having to switch context between UI and API.

### Intended users

* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

#### Use cases

* A user adds release notes to a tag, but realizes this is not the right tag and wants to easily remove the release 
* A user wants to delete a historical release on the release page for hygiene, but still wants to be able to pull historical releases via API.

### Proposal

[ðŸŒˆ SEE PROTOTYPES IN THE `DESIGN` TAB](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213862/designs/release__edit.png)

#### Acceptance criteria

* Users should be able to delete a release through the UI.
* In the `edit` view of a release entry, a button to delete the release should be added to the bottom of the page.
  * Permission: Only **Mantainers** should see the button. For all other roles, it should not be rendered in the UI.
  * ~frontend: Use [gitlab-ui button, type danger](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/iframe.html?id=base-button--default&knob-category=tertiary&knob-variant=danger&knob-size=medium)
  * Button label should read: `Delete release`
* Clicking the `Delete release` button in the `edit release` form should trigger confirmation a modal. The copy should read:
  * ~frontend: Use [gitlab-ui modal component](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/base-modal--default).
    * Modal title: `Delete release`
    * Modal body: `You are about to delete <release_name>. The related Git tag remains, and the assets from this release can still be found in the <tag_page>. Read more about <deleting a release>. Are you sure you want to continue?`
      * the `<tag_page>` should link to the detail view of the tag associated to the release. `<deleting a release>` should link to the documentation anchor for release deletion.
    * Buttons: `Cancel` and `Delete`
  * Clicking `Cancel` closes the modal. No action is performed.
  * Clicking `Delete release` closes the modal and triggers an action to delete the release entry. 
* If the user confirms the deletion of a release in the modal, the browser should redirect the user to the `Releases` overview page.
* **Deleting a release should `NOT` delete the Git tag and evidence collection.**
* In the `Releases` overview page, the deleted release entry should be removed from the UI.
* A toast component should be displayed in the UI, with a confirmation message.
  * ~frontend: Use [gitlab-ui toast component](https://design.gitlab.com/components/toast).
  * **Please note: the prototype displays an alert, but the implementation should use a Toast component.**
  * The toast should be dismissible (display the _close_ button).

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?-->

* Only Developers and above should be able to delete Releases.
* If a user does not have access to delete a Release, they should not see the delete button in the UI.

#### Out of scope

* We can also consider in a future iteration restoration of deleted Releases.
* For this iteration, we won't consider going through an approval process for deleting a Release. Later on, deleting a release would kick off a merge request for the Project Owner/Maintainer to Approve prior to approval   

### Documentation

Yes, this feature requires a new documentation on the Releases Docs Page. ~"Technical Writing" 

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

* When a release is deleted a tag should not be deleted 
* The Release and Release View Page should be removed when someone deletes the release from the UI (and API for that matter) 

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this. -->

Users will be able to delete releases through the UI.

### What is the type of buyer?

<!-- WhatÂ isÂ theÂ buyerÂ personaÂ forÂ thisÂ feature?Â SeeÂ https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/buyer-persona/
In which enterprise tier should this feature go? See https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers -->

* Core/Community 

### Links / references

* Pajamas modal guidelines - https://design.gitlab.com/components/modals/
* Pajamas toast guidelines - https://design.gitlab.com/components/toast

title: Existing notes on merge requests aren't displayed on merge (head) version
description:
Support for merge-ref-comments has been introduced at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28623. The existing notes don't have `diff_note_positions` generated for them, i.e they aren't going to be displayed on merge-ref-head diff until the mergeability check is run for a merge request.

We need either to migrate data (which may turn up to be a high-load operation) or generate the data on the fly, when merge-ref-head version is requested

Possible solution: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28623#note_319336227

Related issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/198457

## Feature flags

```
return unless Feature.enabled?(:merge_ref_head_comments, @merge_request.target_project, default_enabled: true)
return unless Feature.enabled?(:merge_red_head_comments_position_on_demand, @merge_request.target_project, default_enabled: true)
```

title: MR detects new, fixed vulnerabilities when switching to non-DinD setup
description:
## Summary

The Security Scanning widget detects new, fixed vulnerabilities in a merge request that switches Dependency Scanning configuration from Docker-in-Docker setup to non-DinD setup.

As a side-effect, vulnerability feedback is lost.

This issue might affect SAST as well. See [discussion](#note_320249980).

### Further details

The DinD orchestrator [loops over the Docker images](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/v2.9.0/orchestrator/orchestrator.go#L88) of the Dependency Scanning (DS) analyzers, in the order defined in `DS_DEFAULT_ANALYZERS` in the [configuration template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml#L10). This order has an impact when [merging the reports](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/v2.9.0/orchestrator/orchestrator.go#L174) using [issue.MergeReports](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/v2.9.0/issue/report.go#L105), which in turn delegates to [issue.Dedupe](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/v2.9.0/issue/dedupe.go#L23).
In the non-DinD setup, the order in which DS reports are processed is not deterministic,
so the Rails backend might generate a different result when [removing the duplicates](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v12.9.2-ee/ee/app/services/security/merge_reports_service.rb#L108), even though the logic is the same. The deduplication logic was introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/commit/887812d6788ee015075c34823fc7761ecffcae18

### Steps to reproduce

Create a project where Docker-in-Docker Dependency Scanning is enabled in the `master` branch, and create a MR that switches to non-DinD Dependency Scanning.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/ruby-bundler/-/merge_requests/80

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The Security Scanning widget lists new vulnerabilities and fixed vulnerabilities.

```
Security scanning detected 11 new, and 9 fixed vulnerabilities
```

New vulnerabilities:

```
Unknown Untrusted Search Path in ffi
Unknown Improper Input Validation in nokogiri
Unknown Access of Resource Using Incompatible Type (Type Confusion) in nokogiri
Unknown Improper Input Validation in nokogiri
Unknown Use After Free in nokogiri
Unknown Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling in puma
Unknown Cross-site Scripting in rack
Unknown Information Exposure in rack
Unknown Uncontrolled Resource Consumption in rack
Unknown Cross-site Scripting in sinatra
Unknown Path Traversal in sinatra
```

Fixed vulnerabilities:

```
High ruby-ffi DDL loading issue on Windows OS
Medium sinatra ruby gem path traversal via backslash characters on Windows
Unknown Nokogiri gem, via libxml, is affected by DoS and RCE vulnerabilities
Unknown Nokogiri gem, via libxml2, is affected by multiple vulnerabilities
Unknown Revert libxml2 behavior in Nokogiri gem that could cause XSS
Unknown Nokogiri gem, via libxslt, is affected by multiple vulnerabilities
Unknown Possible DoS vulnerability in Rack
Unknown Possible XSS vulnerability in Rack
Unknown XSS via the 400 Bad Request page
```

![Capture_d_eÌcran_2020-04-08_16.57.42](/uploads/a15b1659967279f812cca42db1bd7d20/Capture_d_eÌcran_2020-04-08_16.57.42.png)

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The Security Scanning widget lists no vulnerabilities because the MR introduces no new vulnerabilities, and fixes no existing ones.

### Possible fixes

A quick hack would be to update the [`MergeReportsService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v12.9.2-ee/ee/app/services/security/merge_reports_service.rb#L4) to sort the vulnerability findings/occurrences prior to removing the duplicates, using the current value of `DS_DEFAULT_ANALYZERS` as a source of truth. See [Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml#L10
):

```yaml
  DS_DEFAULT_ANALYZERS: "bundler-audit, retire.js, gemnasium, gemnasium-maven, gemnasium-python"
```

We could do the same for SAST.

Ultimately we should improve the deduplicate logic so that [`MergeReportsService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v12.9.2-ee/ee/app/services/security/merge_reports_service.rb#L4) does not depend on a hard-coded list.

Ideally, the Rails backend would store all the vulnerability findings, and deduplicate them when rending the list for the UI.

### Implementation Plan

Hard code priority to scanners and sort them something like following 

```ruby 
  def sort_by_ds_analyzers
      analyzer_priorities = {
        "bundler_audit" => 1,
        "retire.js" =>  2,
        "gemnasium" => 3,
        "gemnasium-maven" => 3,
        "gemnasium-python" => 3
      }.freeze

      @source_reports.sort! do |a, b|
        a_scanner_id, b_scanner_id = a.scanners.values[0].external_id, b.scanners.values[0].external_id

        analyzer_priorities[a_scanner_id] <=> analyzer_priorities[b_scanner_id]
      end
    end

```
Orchestrator layer was deduping reports in certain order. In that way we can imitate behaviour of orchestrator layer and have same output when switching no-dind. 


### Availability and Testing

SET should add an end to end test to support non-DinD branches.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

title: Prevent user from closing browser tab with not submitted review comments
description:
<!--Â TheÂ firstÂ threeÂ sections:Â "ProblemÂ toÂ solve",Â "IntendedÂ users"Â andÂ "Proposal",Â areÂ stronglyÂ recommended,Â whileÂ theÂ restÂ ofÂ theÂ sectionsÂ canÂ beÂ filledÂ outÂ during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.Â -->

### Problem to solve

The review feature is awesome! But I sometimes forget to press "Submit review" button before leaving merge request page. That causes unnecessary cycle when author asks me to submit my comments and I do so which leads to delay(sometimes up to a full day due to time-zone differences).

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

(hard to choose, basically everyone who uses review feature)

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)
* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops) -->

### Proposal

Google Music shows me confirm dialog when I try to close the tab with playing music:

![Screenshot_2020-04-08_at_12.59.37](/uploads/2ebe625212234d795b294f84971e6c56/Screenshot_2020-04-08_at_12.59.37.png)

I think as MVC we can do the same if there are not submitted review comments.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

A slightly shorter merge cycle time for gitlab-org?

title: Make Geo Node Form Errors even more User Friendly
description:
## Problem
After the merging of the MVC for better error messages found here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/29079

The errors now explain the situation but are not very easy to read:
![Screen_Shot_2020-04-07_at_2.35.04_PM](/uploads/39489ee3792c190208a4776786bcea1b/Screen_Shot_2020-04-07_at_2.35.04_PM.png)

## Proposal

Use `GlAlert`
*  Remove the use of Flash.Js and instead use the `GlAlert` component. This will allow for multi-line errors like mentioned here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/29079#note_319911391

On Change Error Messages:
1. Where possible, do form validation on change, so the user get instant feedback
2. Lock the save button when an error is present

On Save Error Messages:
1. Since the API returns errors in relation to the field that caused them, after a failed save, have the field light up with its error
2. Revert the onSaveError Flash message to be something like "Error saving Geo node, see errors below."

## Proposed design

- [Sketch prototype](https://www.sketch.com/s/vDp03/p/validations)

### Form validation

![error](/uploads/4d7858174523582919bfb021147598af/error.png)

- On change error, when users apply the change on the field but if it does not match with our rule, then we show errors on the form. (Instant validation) 

### Alerts

![save-error](/uploads/d1d202a5dca7b2137a57dde766609227/save-error.png)

## Error messages

### Messages on the forms

| Fields | Primary | Secondary |
| ------ | ------ |------ |
| Node name | `Node name can't be blank` | `Node name can't be blank`| 
| URL | `URL can't be blank` | `URL can't be blank` |
| URL | `URL must be a valid URL` | `URL must be a valid URL` | 
| Capacity (number of jobs) related fields | `The number should be between 1-999` | `The number should be between 1-999` | 
| Re-verification interval (in days) | - | `The number should be between 1-999` :nerd: |


### Messages on the alert

| Alert message | Primary | Secondary |
| ------ | ------ |------ |
| Common | `Error saving the node, see errors below.` | `Error saving the node, see errors below.`| 

- Show the error message on clicking the save

### Scope of the value on the fields

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213732

## References

- [Disabled button](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/base-button--default)
- [Form validation - behavior](https://design.gitlab.com/components/forms/#validation)

title: Backend: Parent/Child: variable defined in manually triggered pipeline UI should be sent to children
description:
### Release notes

Pipeline variables (such as variables defined in the UI or API) based on https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/variables/#cicd-variable-precedence hold the highest priority, however, this is not the case when using a downstream pipeline (such as parent-child or multi-project pipeline), in this release we've added the ability to for a downstream pipeline to inherit pipeline variables from upstream.

### Problem to solve

In a parent pipeline, with child pipelines in the same project (not multi-project pipeline), variable values defined for this pipeline in the manual trigger UI should be transmitted to children as-well.

However, this is not the case today, as can be seen with the following reproducer:

.gitlab-ci.yml
```yaml
#UI_DEFINED_VARIABLE is to be define in pipeline UI (local to one pipeline manually triggered)

parent:
  script:
    - echo "UI_DEFINED_VARIABLE is ${UI_DEFINED_VARIABLE}"

trigger-child:
  trigger:
    include: child-ci.yml
    strategy: depend
```

child-ci.yml
```yaml
child:
  script:
    - echo "UI_DEFINED_VARIABLE is ${UI_DEFINED_VARIABLE}"
```

I think this makes sense because the intent of parent/child pipeline ([per documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/parent_child_pipelines.html)) is to enhance readability of one large pipeline, not to divide them in small independent ones.

### Intended users

Anyone using manual trigger to test their pipeline with specific configuration.

As an example, when creating a rule for a specific branch, I always create a corresponding test rule with a variable so that I can emulate the behavior on a different branch (e.g. for debugging purpose).

### Note

This probably apply to API triggered pipelines.

@thaoyeager I think this should be placed in the [parent/child epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2750)

### Workaround

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/multi_project_pipelines.html#passing-variables-to-a-downstream-pipeline

```yaml
trigger-child:
  trigger:
    include: child-ci.yml
  variables:
    UI_DEFINED_VARIABLE: $UI_DEFINED_VARIABLE
```


in case you would like to transmit a non-existent variables to be evaluated literally in the child if they don't exist on the parent.

The workaround above will not work if the variable to be propagated is not defined in the parent (e.g. only provided when triggering the pipeline manually).

In that case the parent should specify the variable top-level:

Parent `.gitlab-ci.yml`:

```yaml
image: alpine

variables:
  VAR_TO_PROPAGATE: ""
child:
  trigger:
    include: child.yml
  variables:
    VAR_IN_CHILD: $VAR_TO_PROPAGATE
```

Child `child.yml`:

```yaml
if-var:
  script: echo $VAR_IN_CHILD
  rules:
    - if: $VAR_IN_CHILD != ""

if-not-var:
  script: echo
  rules:
    - if: $VAR_IN_CHILD == ""
```

This runs the job `if-not-var` by default and when I define `VAR_TO_PROPAGATE` when running the pipeline manually, it [runs the job ](https://gitlab.com/fabiopitino/test/-/pipelines/240394178)`if-var`


### Proposal

Add a `forward` keyword nested under `trigger` with 2 nested value
- `yaml_variables: true` - will represent the current/default behavior
- `pipeline_variables: true` - with this, pipeline UI variables are passed


```yaml
variables:
  BAR: bar

trigger-downstream:
  variables:
    FOO: foo
  trigger:
    include: child.yml
    forward: # I nested this keyword under trigger
      yaml_variables: true # this is the current/default behavior
      pipeline_variables: true # with this, pipeline UI variables are passed
```

```yaml
trigger-downstream:
  trigger:
    project: namespace/project-2
    forward: # I nested this keyword under trigger
      yaml_variables: true # this is the current/default behavior
      pipeline_variables: true # with this, pipeline UI variables are passed
```

title: Investigate limits for the Package Registry
description:
~"backend-weight::2" 

## Topic to Evaluate
The GitLab Package Registry allows you to publish and install packages in a variety of formats to your GitLab instance. This issue proposes investigating the possibility and scope of adding limits to the GitLab Package Registry. 

This investigation is part of the broader epic https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/1422, which aims to add limits for the Package stage.

## Questions
### _What limits are currently in place for the GitLab Package Registry. [(This includes all package manager formats)](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/)_

#### File Size

| Package Type | Max Size |
|--------------|----------|
| NPM | None |
| Maven | None |
| Conan | 50 MB |
| NuGet | 50 MB |
| PyPI | 50 MB |

For Conan/NuGet/PyPI, these are controlled [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6d9b901d74c190c0e92b2dde7b96e79acc49e536/ee/lib/api/helpers/packages_helpers.rb#L6) and can be modified per package type in the `authorize_workhorse!` call (hardcoded).

Maven could easily be modified by adjusting it to use `authorize_workhorse!`, or by passing it in as a param in it's file upload endpoint (hardcoded).

NPM is the only package manager *[not](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6d9b901d74c190c0e92b2dde7b96e79acc49e536/ee/app/services/packages/npm/create_package_service.rb)*[ using workhorse uploads](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6d9b901d74c190c0e92b2dde7b96e79acc49e536/ee/app/services/packages/npm/create_package_service.rb) (it uses carrierwave and accepts the file directly), there is no current limit.

#### Current File Name and Type exclusion

| Package Type | File exclusions |
|--------------|-----------------|
| NPM | None. I believe we can restrict to only `.tgz` files. File names are validated with the standard package name regex. |
| Maven | None. We should be able to restrict to `.xml, .pom, .jar` files. File names are validated with a Maven specific regex. |
| Conan | Yes. Only specific file names and types are [allowed](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/lib/ee/gitlab/regex.rb#L9) defined in [`ConanFileMetadatum`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/models/packages/conan_file_metadatum.rb#L20). This has proven to be an issue because some files that should be allowed were not known during implementation, preventing some use cases. There is a list of files in the conan source code [here](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/conans/paths/__init__.py#L25), but it is unclear which are the allowed upload files and which are other files, so some investigation will be needed to update. |
| NuGet | Yes. Only `.nupkg` files are allowed. File names are validated with the standard package name regex |
| PyPI | None. We should be able to restrict to `tar.gz` and `.whl` files. File names are validated with the standard package name regex |

#### Current registry storage limits

There is currently no limit (that I can tell) to the amount of storage that can be used for files in the package registry at the project, group, or instance levels.- Are there sensible, non-controversial limits that can be easily added

### _Are there specific file types that we should exclude?_

Yes, for each package manager, we should only allow the specific filetypes that package manager uses. 

### _Can we consider adding storage limits in the future? Can they be enforced?_

We can add limits likely at the project, group, or instance level. We can limit the total size, or total number of packages. 

#### Total number

This would be the easiest route, we could add settings at any of the above levels that could be configured by admin users. Enforcing would be as easy as checking how many packages exist within a given project/group/instance when someone tries to push a new package and rejecting if the limit has been met. Each level would be it's own issue here, each likely having a weight of 3, needing both frontend and backend work.

#### Total size

Similar to number, we could add settings at the above levels for admin users to configure. Enforcing this is a bit more difficult. I'm not sure how we could quickly go about calculating the amount of space taken up by packages. I'm thinking perhaps it could be saved in the database (in a project or group supplemental statistics table) and updated anytime someone pushes or deletes a package. Doable, but likely a larger issue. Each level would be it's own issue here, they would all be somewhat large, >5, and need to be broken down into a few steps to be implemented.

### _How could we implement the above?_

See the proposed issues and the storage limits comments.

#### Proposed Issues 

I've added a rough weight estimate to each

- `1` Restrict NPM packages to `.tgz` file type
- `1` Restrict Maven packages to `.xml`, `.pom`. and `.jar` files. 
- `1` Restrict PyPI packages to `.tar.gz` and `.whl` files.
- `2` Consider tighter naming restrictions for Maven, NPM, NuGet, and PyPI based on any restriction within their own package manager rules
- `1` Limit Maven package files to 50MB
- `2` Limit NPM package files to 50MB


## Tasks
- [x] Create issue for implementation or update existing implementation issue description with implementation proposal 
- [x] Set weight on implementation issue
- [x] If weight is greater than 5, break issue into smaller issues

## Risks and Implementation Considerations

Setting a limit, specifically on size is a large undertaking. With the proposed idea of storing a constantly updating value in the database, the work might look like:

For Project level:

1.  `1` Database migration to add storage columns to a project_statistics table
2.  `2-3` Background migration to determine storage for existing projects and update the table.
3.  `1-2`(x5) Update package manager code to update the stats every time a package is uploaded/deleted.
4.  `1` Database migration to add limit settings to project table.
5.  `1` Frontend migration for limit settings
6.  `1` Frontend migration for displaying current storage usage or amount remaining
7.  `2` Add logic to reject package uploads when a package is uploaded after the limit is met.

The breakdown would be similar for group or instance level. 

# Resulting Issues:

### Size limits

- [Maven file size limit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/218014)

title: Installing NPM package from different namespace with CI_JOB_TOKEN fails with 404
description:
### Summary

If you pull/install an NPM package from a public project with the `CI_JOB_TOKEN`, then it will fail with `404`.
Without that token, it will succeed.

### Steps to reproduce

`user2` tries to download/install the `@root/somepackage`, which is a public project.


```
# this line would suffice, since the project is public
@root:registry=https://<gitlab-url>/api/v4/packages/npm/

# but, by adding the following line, you'll a 404 error when you try to install
//<gitlab-url>/api/v4/packages/npm/:_authToken=${CI_JOB_TOKEN}
```

And then install in a job, i.e. `npm install @root/somepackage`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

You should be able to pull it, especially since that works when you do not specify an authToken.

### Root cause

Users can consume packages from the GitLab package registry in their CI pipelines. Packages belong to projects. It is common for users to authenticate using a CI_JOB_TOKEN when working in CI jobs.

Currently, if a user consumes/installs a package from a public project in a pipeline for a different project, the package is successfully installed because the request is anonymous, and the code will check `Ability.allowed?(nil, :read_package, public_project)` and `Ability.allowed?(nil, :read_project, public_project)`. Anonymous users have both `:read_package` and `:read_project` permissions for public projects, so both will return `true` and the CI job will succeed.

However, if a job is authenticated using the CI_JOB_TOKEN, the code will check `Ability.allowed?(ci_job_token, :build_read_project, public_project)`, which will return `false`, and despite being a public project, the package installation will fail.

So why are we checking `:build_read_project` instead of `:read_project` (which will return true for the ci_job_token)?

In the `find_project!` helper, when dealing with CI job token authentication, we try to limit the permissions of the job user. This happens here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/572bb8c0fe055eb32030a8b48764113d8fe2aa6f/ee/lib/ee/api/helpers.rb#L93. You can see that when a user is present, we check `:read_project`, but when a CI_JOB_TOKEN is present, we check `:build_read_project`.

### The Fix

Update the permissions to also allow `:build_read_project` for public projects.

title: Dependency Scanning fails for projects using gradle in offline mode
description:
### Main issue

This is a [sub-issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/issues/4588) for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/33720.

### Problem to solve

In order to support offline environment deployments (air-gap) for Dependency Scanning on gradle projects, we need to avoid making external calls at runtime in the [gemnasium-maven analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven).

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)

### Further details

[gemnasium-maven analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven) tries to install `gemnasium-gradle-plugin` and other resources when running. 

### Proposal

bundle all necessary requirements within the [gemnasium-maven analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven) docker image or provide a way for users to download it and make it available to the analyzer.


### Implementation Plan

- [x] add `gemnasium-gradle-plugin` at build time
- [x] add minimium set of maven plugins required to build gemnasium project

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?-->

### Documentation

If this requires user setup, then we must update user documentation.

### Availability & Testing

- [x] Test solution on the airgap-test instance: https://gitlab-airgap-test.us-west1-b.c.group-secure-a89fe7.internal/tests/maven-with-local-registry 

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Maven projects can be successfully scanned in an offline environment.

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

No.

description:
Currently, the `rspec * quarantine` jobs are run on all `master` commits but we never look at them and they're actually non-actionable.

We should stop running them entirely.

title: Quick Navigation from Search Bar
description:
### Release Notes

When searching through GitLab, sometimes you just need to go to a specific project and not a search result page. 

In the Global search bar, you can now quickly jump to Recent Issues, Groups, Projects, Settings, and Help topics. 

Documentation: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/search/#issues-and-mrs-assigned-to-you-or-created-by-you

Image: ![Quick_Search_Example](/uploads/b861f5637e6edcb5b1b1ff888fcd1c47/2020-09-12_13.48.12.gif)


### Problem

When starting a search from the global nav search bar, results for projects and groups are returned inside of that dropdown. This poses two issues:

1. The dropdown has a noticeable delay to load and show the various scopes while it retrieves those results.
1. A Maximum of 5 results is returned with no way to navigate to get more or know if that's all of the results.

### Proposal

We should remove the search results from the search dropdown. This will help to to speed up the search dropdown and provide information on the available scopes faster, as well as prevent any confusion over those results.

#### Backup plan

If users found this feature valuable it should be re-implemented with some kind of lazy load so that the scopes are still instantly select-able and then those results can load in later. This will keep the performance of the search up navigation high.

title: Review Apps Environments for merge request branches are not stopped upon merge/reject
description:
### Summary
Our current setup follows the review app approach of GitLab. An environment is created for every branch that is part of a merge request, and is supposed to be stopped once the merge request has been accepted/closed. The latter does not work.

```yaml
deployReviewApp:
  # Use an image that provides helm and kubectl
  image: dtzar/helm-kubectl:3.1.1
  stage: reviewApp
  before_script:
    - prepareDeployment
  script:
    - deployReviewApp
  environment:
    name: mr-$CI_MERGE_REQUEST_IID
    url: http://URL/mr-$CI_MERGE_REQUEST_IID
    on_stop: deleteReviewApp
  only:
    - merge_requests

deleteReviewApp:
  image: dtzar/helm-kubectl:3.1.1
  stage: reviewApp
  before_script:
    - prepareDeletion
  script:
    - deleteReviewApp
  when: manual
  environment:
    name: mr-$CI_MERGE_REQUEST_IID
    action: stop
  only:
    - merge_requests
```

I am pretty sure this worked about two months ago, where I tested it manually (by creating and closing merge requests).

### Steps to reproduce

Use the provided snippet above. There is no need to properly set up an application in any way.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The environments are *not* stopped, which leads to tens of instances idling in our cluster.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The environment is stopped once the merge request is accepted/closed, which triggers the deletion of the review app.

### Related issues

There is a fairly large amount of issues similar to this one, although they are all closed, the described behaviour persists. Multiple entries in forums etc. confirm the correctness of the expected behaviour.

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/-/merge_requests/7355
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/-/issues/26102
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/-/issues/60885

title: Bug in notes creation response
description:
There is a bug introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/commit/b96ca8d90fea96adddf38799da200425daefb399

```ruby
      # Allow consumers to detect problems applying commands
      note.errors.add(:commands, _('Commands did not apply')) unless message.present?
```

This is incorrect because `message` here actually contains both success and error messages. Meaning, if `message` contained an error, `note.errors[:commands]` won't be set and then in this block of code:

```ruby
          if note.errors.keys == [:commands_only]
            status 202
            present note, with: Entities::NoteCommands
          elsif note.valid?
            present note, with: Entities.const_get(note.class.name, false)
          else
            note.errors.delete(:commands_only) if note.errors.has_key?(:commands)
            bad_request!("Note #{note.errors.messages}")
          end
```

We'd always get a `202` even if the quick actions had some errors.

I think we need to clean up how we pass these messages in the response because passing success messages in a model's `error` hash is confusing and can lead to wrong assumptions like this. This can be done with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213679 where we want to separate the success and error messages in the frontend.

cc @alexkalderimis

title: Users not added to project as members after Import if project does not have any relations authored by users
description:
Consider the following scenario: 

1. A user creates an empty project (with or without repository) 
2. Same user invites several users to members 
3. User exports and imports created project
4. Members list of imported project will only include project creator 

This is happening because `members_mapper.map` never ran https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/import_export/base/relation_factory.rb#L115-114 

Even if project members never authored anything, it should still be possible to import project members.

title: Remove deprecated Release Evidence endpoints
description:
### Problem to solve

In the [Multiple Evidences for a Release ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/26509) MR, we added multiple Evidences for each Release, and these were added as an array in the [Release Entity](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/entities/release.rb#L37).

In the older, single Evidence per Release model, the Evidence fields were at the root level. As a workaround to prevent a breaking change in a 12.x release, the first Evidence was duplicated in the original fields. The two fields are:

- `evidence_sha`
- `evidence_file_path`

These original fields need to be removed in 13.0

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/entities/release.rb#L35

title: Follow-up from "Add a button to export CSV data"
description:
The following discussion from !26838 should be addressed:

- [ ] @markrian started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/26838#note_318647468):  (+2 comments)

    > **Not blocking**: While persisting to local storage is fine, especially for an MVC, the UX could be improved by instead persisting to the database via `user_callouts_helper`. This way, the state of the popover will persist across all browsers (or the same browser after a `localStorage.clear()`) for the  user.
    > 
    > See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/22117 for an example of how to do that. There's also a video which goes through another implementation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wJmI4tA92L8.
    > 
    > That said, it's a fair bit more code for a marginal UX improvement, especially when you have to pass through a handful of values from the backend to a descendant component :shrug: 
    > 
    > With all that said, assuming you'll keep this `localStorage` implementation, I'd recommend that you open a follow-up issue to track clearing up this data for when the popover gets removed.
    > 
    > Thoughts?

title: Include total project snippet repository size in project statistics
description:
At the moment, when a wiki or a project repository receives a push, we expire and recalculate some of the project statistics, in order to have, for example, an accurate storage size. 

Now, with snippets having repositories, I think we should include this metric. 

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213526 we expire the snippet repository size. Therefore, when we call the `ProjectCache` worker, all the snippet repository sizes should be up to date. The task will be to sum al the snippet repo sizes and include them in the overall project storage size.

Basically, we can:
- Add a column in `ProjectStatistics` like `snippets_size`
- In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/workers/post_receive.rb#L75, add a call to call like `ProjectCacheWorker.perform_async(project.id, [], [:snippets_size])` after we expire the snippet repository size cache.
- Update the `ProjectStatistic` model to include this new `snippets_size` metric 
- We should also call the `ProjectCacheWorker` when we remove a snippet.
- Include the new metric in those views we show them (at the moment I'm only aware of the Admin section)


### Test Activity

@fjsanpedro:
* Test that the statistics are updated properly when the repository is updated (more size/lower size)

@vij:
* Test statistic is incremented correctly
* Test statistic is decremented correctly
* Test statistic is included in admin views


### MR Breakdown

@fjsanpedro:

We need to update one table in the database, the related class to include snippets, and also the places when we render this statistics, which can be views or API endpoints.

* 1 MR to add the column to the database 
* 1 MR to update the main class
* 1 MR to update API endpoints
* 1 MR to update views

title: Back 'Vulnerabilities over time' report with Standalone Vulnerability data on Instance & Group Security Dashboard
description:
### Problem to solve

The 'Vulnerabilities over time' report found on the Instance & Group level Security Dashboards should reflect same Standalone Vulnerability data used to populate the Vulnerability list. 

### Further details

The decision was made as part of the Standalone Vulnerabilities MVC to leave this report back by the original "findings" data. While it was acknowledged at the time that this could be confusing for customers, due to time constraints we're choosing to address this data source in future iteration. 

### Proposal

Update 'Vulnerabilities over time' UI & endpoints to ensure data on report is aligned with the Standalone vulnerability data that drives the rest of the dashboard. No other UI or content changes are needed.

title: Display Vulnerability file paths on Security Dashboards (project, group & instance)
description:
### Problem to solve

Our current Security Dashboard in production (ie. pre-Standalone Vulnerabilities) displays the file path of each vulnerability.  To achieve parity with our offering today & match the designs provided by UX, we should update our Vulnerability list on the security dashboard to display the file path of each vulnerability listed. 

### Further details

The Standalone Vulnerability page will also display the file path as part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/201813. 

### Proposal

The file path is available through the location field. The field returns a string that can be parsed into JSON, which isn't the best, but it was the quickest. @avielle created https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/208847 to make it a proper GraphQL object later (post MVC/12.10)

### Permissions and Security

All of this should be behind the `first_class_vulnerabilities` feature flag.

title: Verify the DAST CI template works with new DAST features
description:
## What is the productivity problem to solve?

When a new DAST feature is released, the engineer must manually check to verify that the feature works with the latest DAST CI template. This results in engineer time wasted, and introduces defects when the testing is not as thorough as one might hope, or when testing is performed differently by different engineers.

### Problem identification checklist

- [ ] The DAST template at the `HEAD` of GitLab Rails `master` should be tested with each DAST releasable image

## What is the potential solution?

- [ ] Include in the DAST pipeline a test using the GitLab Rails template
- [ ] Test a standard website
- [ ] Test using an API scan
- [ ] Tests should *loosly* care about the report output. The Job should fail if DAST does not run successfully. The Job should not fail over and over because the vulnerability definitions change.
- [ ] Remove the [qa-dast.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-dast.yml) template. Any configuration for the DAST CI Pipeline should be in the DAST codebase.

title: Fix inconsistent namespace usage in the security dashboards
description:
This is a follow up of [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28652#note_318794762): 

> Apparently we have a lot of inconsistencies. I was able to catch 4 types of names in our security dashboards:
> 1. Global namespace
> 1. `Security Dashboard`
> 1. `SecurityDashboard`
> 1. `Security Reports`
> 
> After implementing the suggested changes I've seen all these inconsistencies and figured that opening a new issue for this is more appropriate. Since I'm not adding any new translation here, but reusing the same ones from different components I would suggest that I keep these strings as they are and fix the inconsistencies in a separate MR. WDYT?

The problem is that we are using different namespaces for translations in the Security Dashboards. This creates confusion. It would be nice to stick to one.

title: `diffs_metadata` commit next and prev commit SHAs are reversed
description:
### Summary

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/27528/diffs, we added the `next_commit_id` and `prev_commit_id` fields to the `commit` so that the ~frontend can move commit-by-commit.

However, due to some discrepancy between real behavior and our mocks, the values in these fields are actually reversed.

### Steps to reproduce

- Create some number of commits in a branch (3 is the minimum needed to get all of the possible combinations)
- Create an MR from that branch
- Visit the `Commits` tab of the MR, and click the first (chronologically) commit. This is the commit at the bottom of the list.
- Note the response to the request for the `diffs_metadata.json` endpoint

### Example Project

Any project using an instance of GitLab on `master`, so anything local or (as of this writing) GitLab.com **CANARY**.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The `next_commit_id` contains the "previous" SHA - or you can think of this value as being "farther from the tip of the branch".  
The `prev_commit_id` contains the "next" SHA - or you can think of this value as being "closer to the tip of the branch".

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

`next_commit_id` should contain a SHA that moves me closer to the tip of the branch, or `null` if I'm already at the tip.  
`prev_commit_id` should contain a SHA that moves me farther away from the tip of the branch, or `null` if I'm already at the first commit in the branch.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Below you'll find a `git log` for my own test repository and the response of my own network request. The latter is truncated heavily to focus on the relevant bits:

`git log`

```shell
(14:18:19)|thomas:personal $ git log --oneline
3bbd5db (HEAD -> multiple-commits, origin/multiple-commits) Expand with "changes."
8e167b6 Expand with "some"
12ac458 Expand with "has"
d0b6092 Expand with "file"
c4592ac Add text file
810dea6 (origin/master, master) Add a symlink to the webpack config file
```

Response

```javascript
{
  ...
  "commit": {
    "id": "c4592ace638ad9027cdc46e4b022ba293b3202bf",
    ...
    "prev_commit_id": "d0b6092c52a2614f3e5c755e42912d3dd2bed646",
    "next_commit_id": null,
    ...
  },
  ...
}
```

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com **CANARY**, and will happen on production `.com` when the next deploy occurs.

### Possible fixes

In theory [these tests](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/27528/diffs#dedb2179aa4d5d9561ed1c1cb549f2ac437c561c_29_53) should be failing. Because they're not, we may have a larger problem than just "bad logic." It seems the mocked data may not actually be representative of how `gitaly`(?) actually works in reality.

That's the end of my knowledge about RSpec, though :smile:

title: Include changes to approval groups in audit log
description:
<!--Â TheÂ firstÂ threeÂ sections:Â "ProblemÂ toÂ solve",Â "IntendedÂ users"Â andÂ "Proposal",Â areÂ stronglyÂ recommended,Â whileÂ theÂ restÂ ofÂ theÂ sectionsÂ canÂ beÂ filledÂ outÂ during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.Â -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? TryÂ toÂ defineÂ theÂ who/what/whyÂ ofÂ theÂ opportunityÂ asÂ aÂ userÂ story.Â ForÂ example,Â "AsÂ aÂ (who),Â IÂ wantÂ (what),Â soÂ IÂ canÂ (why/value)." -->

Currently, there are gaps in the ~"Category:Audit Events" log for changes made to MR approval settings. Specifically, if an approval group is added or removed, there is no captured audit event. Additionally, if an individual is added or removed to an existing approval group, there is no audit event.

The lack of these events creates a gap in the nonrepudiation posture of a GitLab environment, which can be problematic for audit or compliance stakeholders looking to track down specific information about a change or when satisfying external auditor requirements for evidence of traceability and auditability.

### Intended users

* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* The management stakeholders who adhere to any auditing process. To be defined in a new [Compliance Persona](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/ux-research/issues/546)

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

We addressed some related gaps in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/7531 but customer feedback has highlighted additional areas for improvement.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Capture audit events for:

* Add/Remove an approval group

(suggested copy)
e.g. `Approval Group` was `Added` to `Project` at `Date/Time`

* If I add/remove an individual to an existing approval group, no audit event is listed.

(suggested copy)
e.g. `User` was `Removed` from `Approval Group` at `Date/Time`

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?-->
